Notes:
I'm going to leave "separated the darkness from the light" even though this concept, SEPARATE, is used for physical objects.  The alternative would be pretty complex.  I'm guessing that a literal translation, combined with the rest of the verse, will make sense in almost all languages.

BE sense P is ambience.  "Be hot", "Be cold" or in this case "Be light".  It's possible that hot/cold might be realized differently than light/dark in some languages in which case a transfer rule would be needed.

Notes:
Note that I used EXIST back in verse 1 for "God existed before anything else existed" and here I use the existential sense of BE, as in "Let there BE(exist) a place between the water."

Also, BETWEEN usually is used with two arguments, or at least a plural, count noun (between the signs).  "a place between the water" might have to be translated differently.

Notes: I used "crawl on the ground" instead of "crawl on your stomach" because none of the senses of "on" really fit that and I didn't really want to make a new sense just for this case. I could have used "on your stomach" and assumed the target language would add a transfer rule to change "on" to whatever, but I figured "on the ground" was safer, even though technically snakes can crawl in trees.  But the next part of the verse says "you will eat dust..." so that kind of assumes a ground-crawling animal anyway.

Notes:
""Best part":
This is a pretty interesting example.  For Gen 4:4 we discussed using:

"Abel also brought an offering to God.  Abel killed several of Abel's sheep.  Then Abel brought those sheep's meat to God."

We originally had it like: "Abel also brought an offering to God.  Abel brought the best part of some sheep of Abel."

The thing is, literally the Hebrew has something like "He brought the fat portions of his best sheep to God."  So I don't think we can say "meat".  I actually like the New Century Version that said "the best part of the sheep" because that is really what it means.  To the Hebrews, the fat portion was the best.  To us, the meat portion is the best.  It's an interesting translation example, because when you and I hear "He brought the fat portions to God" we think that he is giving the waste/bad part of it to God, but that's completely wrong.  I think that the New Century Version gets it right with "Abel brought the best parts of from some of the firstborn sheep".

And the Motalava people would definitely say "walk down to the spring".  But I took out the "up/down" for now.

KJV: And, behold, the LORD stood above it, and said, I am the LORD God of Abraham thy father, and the God of Isaac: the land whereon thou liest, to thee will I give it, and to thy seed;

Verse: There are many pieces of dust on the earth.  The number of the descendants of you(Jacob) will be like the number of pieces of dust. Notes:
Foreign gods probably refers to the images or idols brought with the people from Mesopotamia, or brought into Jacob’s camp after the looting of Shechem. In order to express this thought, it may be necessary to say, for example, “gods that do not belong here.”
(Reyburn, W. D., & Fry, E. M. (1998). A handbook on Genesis (p. 809). New York: United Bible Societies.)

KJV: When she was brought forth, she sent to her father in law, saying, By the man, whose these are, am I with child: and she said, Discern, I pray thee, whose are these, the signet, and bracelets, and staff.

Verse: [After Judah read the message] Judah saw the ring and the staff.  [When Judah saw the ring and the staff] Judah knew [that the ring and the staff belonged to Judah]. So Judah said, ["Tamar is more righteous than I(Judah)]. Tamar tricked me(Judah) [because I(Judah) did not keep the promise [that I(Judah) made to Tamar]].  I(Judah) did not tell [my(Judah's) son named Shelah to marry Tamar]]." So Judah did not kill Tamar.  And Judah did not sex Tamar again.

Notes:
13 I(servant) am standing by this spring/well. and the womaen [who live in the city] are coming to the spring/well [in-order-to get water].  ;;I see that the NIV switches back and forth between ‘well’ and ‘spring,’ but I think we should choose one or the other and use it consistently.  It doesn’t matter to me which one you use.

My impression was that there was a well AND a spring.  In the Hebrew, there are two different words.  One used in conjunction with the camel (where the camels waited; where Rebekah went to draw water for the camels.  It's BDB definition is "well"), and one used for where Rebekah was getting the water for people to drink (BDB translation "Spring").  So given this, I'm going to keep it as two words and even try to put something in there that makes it clear that the spring is not the same as the well.
